utterances: Vocalists create more than one note simultaneously and weave those tones together.
This is the sort of music Nelson Mandela probably heard while growing up.
Yeah, Paris is a town that's been having troubles for a couple of years now.
There was a case a couple of years ago of a young black girl named Shaquanda Cotton.
She was a 14-year-old girl who was - pushed the home monitor at her high school and for that she was sentenced to - up to seven years in prison by a local judge.
The same judge just a few weeks earlier had given a 14-yea-old white girl a sentence of probation for the crime of arson for burning down a house.
So, the disparities in those sentences are what caused a lot of folks to kind of question what was going on in that town.

Last year, there was a case of a black man who was allegedly murdered - he was murdered, he was allegedly by two white companions who took him out in the truck and ran him over and dragged his body underneath the truck until it was basically dismembered.
There's a lot of black folks in that town who believe it was a hate crime and would like to see it investigated as such.
The two white suspects are awaiting trial on murder charges in that case.
The Justice Department is - sent a special team in to try to mediate disputes in that town.
They had a meeting there last month which pretty much erupted into yells and screams between blacks and whites.
So that reconciliation effort didn't go so well.

And then most recently, there was an incident in a local pipe making factory called Turner Pipe where some black employees alleged that for many months now, they've been complaining without success to their bosses about the nooses and racist graffiti and confederate flags and other offensive symbols that are festooned around the plant.
And finally, one of these employees actually filed a formal complaint with the EEOC, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, a week ago, in which he formally complained about this.
And he had photos of all of these nooses and graffiti and such inside the plant.
And so the plant officials once that complaint was filed said they were shocked by all of this and they ordered it removed and claimed that they didn't know anything about it.
But several of the black employees told me that in fact, this has been a feature in that plant for many months.
Well, let me stop you there because you've given us a litany of things that are taking place.
Let me ask you this, what is the basis of this?
Is it just that black folks and white folks in Paris, Texas do not like each other?
Is it a situation where tensions have been exacerbated by the economic condition?
What is it?
You know, I wish I had an answer for that.
You know, in many ways Paris is not that different than a lot of small towns around America, and not just in the South I would say.
You know, I mean, we have this problem in the North as well.
Paris has a long history of, you know, bitter racial relations.
It was the sight of several notorious lynchings at the Paris Fairgrounds around the turn of the century in the late 1900, so there's that history to contend with.
There's also some real imbalances in the way power is structured than that town, very few African-Americans have any positions of electoral power in the town.

So - and it's also located in east Texas which is in region of the country that is very much deep South and very much - and a lot of critics say it's a place where the civil rights era kind of passed them by.
So there's a history of tensions there, you know, but it's not to say that everyone in that town is you know, is at odds.

I mean, there are certainly a lot of folks both black and white of goodwill who wish that these problems didn't keep recurring, but there's a lot of other folks who basically - a lot of folks insisted there's no problems there, it's just outsiders who are stirring things up and you know, they claim that it if people would just leave Paris alone and they could deal with their own problems.
Butâ€¦
Let me pursue that a little bit more with you because what you have described is a Petri dish of racial intolerance so far.
But the question would be how do you come out of that?
How does this community heal itself and move together forward, if that's possible?
Yeah, I think the town is grappling with precisely that question, and the Justice Department is there to try to help them.
They have this special union at the Justice Department which basically deals with community mediation.
They went into Gino(ph), Louisiana last year to try to help folks after the tensions there erupted.

They do this routinely, and in Paris they've had several meetings, but like I say the most recent one kind of ran off the rails because people were just kind of, you know, very emotional and hot-headed.

I think that a lot of the hopes that they might be able to talk and tamp things down and you know, have interactions led by church leaders and such - you know, there was hopes that that was going to work until again last week, this latest problem erupted at the pipe-making plant, which is kind of set things back again.
So I don't know if anybody sees a path to, you know, reconciliation at this point.

One of the things that we just heard from Mark Potok, the director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, was that hate crime organizations, the number of them is up significantly since the turn of the new millennium.
Are you finding the presence of hate organizations in this area?
You know, it's the - there's not formal groups that kind of, you know, identify themselves.
They don't have a problem with some other towns in the South where there's like, you know, revived Klan groups and such.
I'm aware of the SPLC's research and such.
But it's more - I think it's less formal than that but it's probably no less prevalent.

One of the things I'd like to ask you, because you're a person who has been writing about this and the photographs have been printed and seen around the country - the role of the media in covering this, does it make it better, does it make it worst?
Well, I think that really depends on, you know, literally what skin you're in, you know?
A lot of the - many of the black folks in that town are very happy to see outside attention brought, they hoped that that scrutiny is going to force some changes down there.
But by the same token many of the white folks are just outraged and they think that, you know, this is outsiders meddling in their affairs and they ought to just get their nose out of their business.
There was the local Methodist preacher the last time I was there a month ago who told me that I was no better than a Christ killer but you know, you just kind of have to have thick skin.
Howard, thank you very much.
Sure.
That was Howard Witt, the Southwest bureau chief of the Chicago Tribune.

Maybe it's true that justice delayed is justice denied.
But supporters of a 19th-century resident of California will take what they can get.
In 1890, the California Supreme Court denied a Chinese immigrant's application to the State Bar.
One-hundred twenty-five years later, the court reversed that decision, as NPR's Richard Gonzales reports.
Hong Yen Chang was sent to the United States from his native China in 1872 to be groomed as a diplomat, a bridge between East and West.
His training took him through Andover, Yale, Columbia Law School.
Gabriel Chin teaches at the UC Davis School of Law.
So he really was about as well-integrated as one could be into the establishment at the time.
Charming and well-connected, Chang became the first Chinese-American lawyer in this country when he was admitted to the New York Bar in 1888.
He came to California, where he hoped to serve the growing Chinese community of San Francisco.
But the state Supreme Court here, citing both federal and state laws barring non-citizens from becoming lawyers, denied Chang's bid to join the Bar.
Professor Gabriel Chin.
Hong Yen Chang symbolized all of the people whose ambitions, whose dreams, whose careers were cut off because of their race.
Chin and Asian-Pacific-American law students at UC Davis spearheaded a four-year campaign to get the state Supreme Court to reverse its earlier decision.
In their ruling the California justices said, it is past time to acknowledge that the discriminatory exclusion of Chang from the State Bar of California was a grievous wrong.
The family of Hong Yen Chang is absolutely thrilled.
Rochelle Chong is Chang's grand-niece.
It only took 125 years for the Supreme Court of California to decide that he's qualified to practice law (laughter).
We are absolutely thrilled.
Hong Yen Chang died in Berkeley in 1926 after a career in diplomacy and banking.
He never practiced law in California.
Richard Gonzales, NPR News, San Francisco.
